title: 108_s664
content: The "Investment in America Act of 2003" aims to make permanent a research and development credit to incentivize companies to increase research activities in the United States. The "Investment in America Act of 2003" aims to make permanent the research credit by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes striking subsection (h) in Section 41 and amending paragraph (1) of section 45C(b) by striking subparagraph (D). The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is an increase in rates of alternative incremental credit. SEC. 4 of the "Investment in America Act of 2003" increases rates of alternative incremental credit in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment changes percentages for the election of alternative incremental credit. The effective date for this amendment is for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. The amendment to section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows taxpayers to elect the alternative simplified credit, equal to 12 percent of qualified research expenses exceeding 50 percent of the average expenses for the previous 3 years. The credit under this paragraph applies to taxpayers with no qualified research expenses in any of the 3 preceding taxable years. The credit rate is 6 percent of the qualified research expenses for the taxable year. An election under this paragraph applies to the taxable year for which made and all succeeding taxable years unless revoked. The credit applies to taxpayers with no qualified research expenses in the 3 preceding taxable years. The credit rate is 6 percent of the qualified research expenses for the taxable year. An election under this paragraph applies to the taxable year for which made and all succeeding taxable years unless revoked with the consent of the Secretary. An election under this paragraph may not be made for any taxable year to which an election under paragraph (4) applies. Coordination with Election of Alternative Incremental Credit is also discussed. The amendments made by this section allow taxpayers to make an election under section 41(c)(5) of the Code for the year, which can be revoked with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury. These amendments apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act.
